decisions.description: State reapportionment claims are justiciable in federal court

advocates.advocate_description: for the appellants at argument and reargument
reargued the cause for the appellants
Solicitor General, Department of Justice, as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court

description: A case in which the Court found that redistricting issues present justiciable questions, and in which the Court reframed its political question doctrine.
conclusion: In an opinion which explored the nature of "political questions" and the appropriateness of Court action in them, the Court held that there were no such questions to be answered in this case and that legislative apportionment was a justiciable issue. In his opinion, Justice Brennan provided past examples in which the Court had intervened to correct constitutional violations in matters pertaining to state administration and the officers through whom state affairs are conducted. Brennan concluded that the Fourteenth Amendment equal protection issues which Baker and others raised in this case merited judicial evaluation.
facts_of_the_case: Charles W. Baker and other Tennessee citizens alleged that a 1901 law designed to apportion the seats for the state's General Assembly was virtually ignored. Baker's suit detailed how Tennessee's reapportionment efforts ignored significant economic growth and population shifts within the state.

question: Did the Supreme Court have jurisdiction over questions of legislative apportionment?
name: Baker v. Carr
shelf_id: Call Number: KF101 Series: Constitutional Law Series: Volume 369
title: U.S. Reports: Baker et al. v. Carr et al., 369 U.S. 186 (1962).
scdb_caseName: BAKER et al. v. CARR et al.
